All measurements are in mm.

author: cityshaker

description.text:
Here is a simple Shower Head Holder as as there can be found thousands of here on thingiverse. I just needed one that fits my shower.
It works for shower heads with a shaft about Ø 20 mm. The rod the shower head is attached to should be Ø 22 mm, otherwise you will have to scale or modify the parts.
You might wonder why i chose an M10 and M12 Screw, which, obviously, is a bit heavy for a 400 g shower head. I just had them laying around here - they fit pretty well and its easy to adjust with these so i used them. Feel free to modify the parts so that you can use other screws.
If required, I can deliver the original AutoCAD 2015 files.

You will need • M10 Screw/Bolt with washers and a nut
• M12 Screw/Bolt with washers and a nut

A closed box that can hold nano coated coils for the pain pen. Inside is about 13 cms long.
Thanks to Mister Keshe to help and teach humanity for healthy and more.

title: Diana Lens adaptor for Konstruktor camera

description.text: Using the 'back cap' designed by ComradeQuiche (http://www.thingiverse.com/ComradeQuiche/), I've came up with an adaptor to fit the Diana Lens on the Lomography's Konstruktor camera. The Konstruktor's aperture was designed on the camera body (further from the lens), therefore the strong vignettes on the film plane. I have not tested it on actual film or with other diana lens (eg. fisheye lens, wide angle etc). http://instagram.com/jimmy_phua#

comments.text: Hey dude, Really awesome to finally see a adaptor for the Konstruktor, Do you think that you could also design a adaptor for EOS or Nikkor lenses? That would be really frickin' sweet, man.

description.text:
This is a thing I have been wanting to make in a while.
Finally got to it :) It is a mechanical clamp that locks itself in position when fully closed.
NO other materials needed. Use 1.75mm filament to assemble :)
I had a blast prototyping this :) Its a really good piece... working for real.
Depending on how much infill you use its really strong and can hold on to stuff really strong. I would lov to see a Make or two <3 Video below on assembly :) Video is in Swedish but I made English subtitles for you :)

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Simple Black

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

high

Infill:

50

Notes: Make sure you have support where its needed..
Its really easy to print.. bot don't be cheap on support material :) No other materials needed for assembly like screws and stuff.. only the optional spring that I recommend :) The tip should be printed slower i guess.. I printed it separatly very slow.. took about 20 mins..

<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/hnGZ4pt4bJY" ></iframe>
Swedish audio.. But English sub.. just for you ;)

This is an extension of my recent upload (of a coin in a sphere). This time with a small sphere inside a larger sphere inside a larger sphere... I stopped at a total of three.
You may have noticed that the large green sphere is a little smaller than the large red sphere and I've uploaded stl files for sphere 1 of 3, the smallest through to 2 variants of sphere 3 of 3, the largest.
I've also uploaded an scad file. The design is fully parameterised and comment heavy so it should not be difficult to generate your own spheres.

I made the spheres with an Ultimaker fitted with an E3D hot end so the stl files work with that set up. There is enough room to pop the smaller sphere(s) into place when the build has got high enough while the print is in progress.
The scad file has a cut away preview of a sphere inside another as a help to judging whether enough clearance has been chosen.
I made the spheres in different colours, partly so the photos would be more understandable, and partly just to make the point that this was not constructed from a single piece. Three (or more!) of the same colours would look rather cool, though...

title: OMT² - Hex Allen Key set - Metric - M3 to M10

description.text:
Specs :
1/4"(6.35mm) Hex compatible
Length of the Allen key bit : 20mm Description :
Set of the 6 most commonly used Allen keys (in mm, the imperial version is available : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1381003)
Compatible with any standard bit holder and/or OMT² handles. Update : If you have troubles slicing the files with ReplicatorG, there is now a version without the superscript 2 (called OMT2...)

This is just a tool head. If you need a handle or other tools for your bit holder,
visit : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1381028

This set has been made following the ISO 4762/DIN 912 standards. NO TOLERANCE HAS BEEN APPLIED Depending on your printer precision, it may be a very tight fit. Some extra cleaning work may be needed on the Allen end bit. This will never fully replace a set of metal Allen keys, but that can come in handy sometimes ;) Sizes :

M3 (2.5mm)
M4 (3mm)
M5 (4mm)
M6 (5mm)
M8 (6mm)
M10 (8mm)

This set comes in 3 flavours :

A simple frame designed in half an hour.
Intended for use with 10" props for relatively heavy copters (over 1kg total). Feel free to make "wings" of 3mm acryl rather than 6mm plywood, it might make it lighter. Many thanks to fablab77 (Fablab-MIS&S) for assistance and guidance!

Just lasercut or mill everything (note: the holes are exactly 3mm, so use 2.5mm mill or ensure everything is cut!) and assemble according to the gallery photos.
You'll need 4 top wings, 4 bottom wings, 4 footers, 4 spacers and 1 or 2 central boards.

Now that I have a Microsoft Band 2, I don't always have to have my phone in my pocket, just near me.  My professional job requires me to have my phone near me at all times.  This project was designed to allow a secure way to attach my phone to my tablet bag strap.  It was designed for my iPhone 6 (smaller version) with an otterbox case on it which is pretty big so it should fit many phones.  The basic inside dimensions are 77mm x 13mm with rounded edges (see pictures). It is a 2 piece deisgn with the cross bar printed separately because the straps on my bag were sewn shut and could not be threaded.  The pieces should fit snugly together and a drop of glue on each side or a quick melt with a soldering iron should keep them in place.  The maximum strap width for this device is 40mm.  Simply print 2 of these as the top and bottom are designed the same (to expose the iPhone button and speaker)

A bath bomb defuser. So, I have been getting those chalky bath bombs from Lush lately, and I would have to hold them under running water for it to properly produce bubbles and dissolve. I have made many prototypes and accidental drop tests to come out with this model. I made this in Tinkercad, and you may edit it here. UPDATE
So after a few more baths, I made two variations of my bath bomber to accommodate different wants and desires out of the defusing process. The original would just hold the bath bomb to allow the water to run pass it. But Small chunks would fall through the holes and not properly dissolve due to low water movement in the bath. To mitigate this issue, I basically created a mini bath for the bath bomb! :P Happy bathing! :)

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 5

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

10

Notes: With the walls being so thin, I noticed having a 20% infill caused some cracking with ABS. I recommend 10%, but if you think you'll be prone to dropping it often in the tub like I do, use 15%. I also made the handle thicker so it wouldn't need a high infill if dropped. Took about 3-4 hours to print.

These fun Bookmark Men will be an interactive way to interest kids in 3D printing and reading! 
A great teaching exercise would be to create these bookmarks and personalize them for boys and girls! Add pigtails or funky spike hair to make each one unique!
This fast project could easily be printed and used during school reading weeks.

Printer:

Prusa I3

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

25%

Notes: Adding supports all around will be important for the thin legs. The size as seen is perfect for most book sizes. I would recommend not scaling down but scale up as big as you'd like!

Project Bookmen Objective: create a fun project to spark interest in 3D printing and reading! Audiences: 4th grade and up would be appropriate for this project. Steps: One option for this project is to distribute templates: pictures of the plain bookmark model.
Then have younger grades draw their own designs; hair, clothes, hats etc. on the templates.
To produce the 3D prints, older grades in their technology classes will attempt to 3D design the ideas created by younger grades.
At the end of the project the unique bookmarks will then be distributed during school reading weeks.. Results: This project is meant to be a fun project, either students will learn to be innovative and create unique designs for their bookmarks. As well as create a fun real world application for 3D printing. As well promote a fun atmosphere for learning and reading. Bookmark Template

title: Airtight Dry Box for 3D Printer Filament - Parts

description.text: 3D printed parts needed to build an airtight dry box for 3D printer filament storage. Full instructions can be found at this link to my How-To at Instructables.com. The purpose of this dry box is to prevent printer filament from absorbing moisture in the air. It can be used for keeping filament spools of various sizes (up to ~10" [260mm] diameter) in long term storage and in active use. It also prevents dust and dirt from entering the print head by a foam filter. Lubrication can be added as well, as some people in the 3D printing community have suggested. The PTFE tubing is a nice benefit of this set up, even without a bowden style filament drive, as it prevents kinks and coils from stopping the print.

comments.author: printingSome

comments.text: The push to fit connectors are airtight? I mean: the box it is, so the only way for humidity to get into the box would be the hole where the filaments comes out right? the push to fit would prevent air from entereing?
comments.author: Tinchus2009

comments.text: For the most part yes. The threads were screwed in by warming the plastic (see instructables link in description) so it is good there. The fitting-to-ptfe tube connection is airtight (these type of tube and fitting connections are common for high pressure air lines). The only exception would be the end of my ptfe tube going into the extruder, which I have open ended at this point in time. You could make that more airtight with another fitting at that end depending on your extruder design. For these purposes, the air and humidity that makes it all the way thru that tube and into the box is negligible and hasn't caused any issue.
comments.author: Tinchus2009

comments.text: Have you found any new ways to attach the end to the of the tubing to the extruder?
comments.author: mcfada

comments.text: No, but I haven't really been looking. As I mentioned the tube being open at the end doesn't have any negative effects. I've even stored this dry box with filament in it for several weeks in my car during winter, and for several months in my basement, which is pretty humid compared to other places I'd normally print. I just leave the PTFE tube hanging and technically open during these times.

description.text:
EDIT: Added new version (tension_nut_filament(1)). I didn't account for the increased hub hole on my larger spools which resulted in these spools dragging. New version has an additional 30mm arm length. Also added a toothed clip for holding the filament when not loaded. The clip is based upon thing 630789. This is convenient if you have multiple spools loaded on your EMT at once. 
Based upon the design of coconnor55, I created a version that fits 1/2 inch EMT conduit. The nut was designed using FreeCAD. The filament guide was created using TinkerCAD and combining the nut with the guide arm from coconnor55's filament guide. Printed with 1.75 mm ABS filament. I have found that this greatly reduces filament uncoiling and jumping off of the spool.

title: X-Wing Template Stand and Token Holder

description.text:
This is a remix of two particularly good X-Wing accessories by nestyr and GMBridge. The full footprint is sized to fit in a Stanley bin the same as GMBridge's model, but replaces the damage deck with a template stand. I've added a few to nestyr's stand to make space for range rulers, as well as making slots slightly wider to accommodate acryllic templates. Friction fit lid included for storage and transportation. Holds the following:
5 straight maneuver templates
3 bank maneuver templates
3 turn maneuver templates
3 range rulers
8 pairs of ID tokens
8 pairs of target lock tokens
16 focus, evade, stress, and shield tokens
16 misc tokens (ion, ordnance, stealth, weapons disabled, energy, etc)

description.text:
Rim-Drive Rotary Attachment for engraving cylinder items with your laser. Wine bottles ,glasses, mugs, with easily adjust length and height.
Motor nema17 0.9 degree 400step/rev with this setup provides hardware resolution 0.1mm per step . However stepper driver in my laser machine is set to x8 (Microstep) so that the resulting max resolution of 0.0125mm per step. Used 2GT pulley 16 teeth of aluminum that goes over the belt on gear with 50 teeth (cuted on acrylic with laser) . Belt is 280mm in length and 6 mm width.

It should work fine with both PLA and ABS, however I recommend PLA due to big printing size: 165x175x110 mm You may also scale it or modify it, as sources are provided as well (OpenScad), however if you scale it, you must consider that the box is designed for items with at most 30mm width and the front space is about 25mm width.

title: Na das ist ja ein Ding!

description.text:
Na das ist ja ein Ding! Jetzt sind die Tools um Geocaching Rätsel lösen zu können auch schon auf Thingiverse! (zumindest ein Rätsel kann man damit lösen - 6BZYZ)
Für alle die mit dem Begriff Geocaching nichts anfangen können: auf www.geocaching.com kann Ihnen geholfen werden - für alle andern: happy caching!
Ach ja - wer keinen 3D Drucker anwerfen und nur das das Bild ausdrucken will: 49mm x 49mm wäre die ideale Größe ;)

Well - that's a thing. Now there are things online which help you to solve geocaching quests. Or at least one mystery cache - 6BZYZ. 
If you are lost on geocaching - visit www.geocaching.com - it's a fun worldwide playable treasure-hunt
If you don't like to print it in 3d - you can print the png in the zip file - 49mm x 49 mm would be fine ;)

Die Entstehungsgeschichte... Einer von den beiden dieRIESES hat sich einen 3D-Drucker gekauft. Schwer zu erraten welcher - richtig: der Schwerere ;)
Doch was tut man nun mit dem Ding? Als Informatiker ganz klar - man sucht sich eine passende Sprache um Dinge beschreiben bzw. programmieren zu können. Diese Schablone entstammt den ersten Gehversuchen in OpenSCAD und ist somit eines der ersten Programme die für unseren 3D Drucker geschrieben wurden. Da die 3D-Drucker immer billiger werden bieten sie ein nettes Beschäftigungsfeld im Bereich Hobby und wir haben schon ein paar 3D Objekte gefunden die wir bei unserem nächsten und ersten Multi Cache einsetzen wollen. Da kommen sicher einige gedruckte Dinge zum Einsatz. (Sorry - German text only)

title: Morphism from the Associahedron to its dual, the Triaugmented Triangular Prism.

description.text:
This was created by a student at George Mason University for Math 493, Mathematics Through 3D Printing. This is the third project for the class, prepared on Feb. 21st 2016, with the prompt of: choosing a bounded polyhedron (polytope) and exploring the morphism to its dual. First, a few definitions. A polyhedron is an n-th dimensional object that can be described via number of vertices (0 dimensional), edges (1 dimensional), faces (2 dimensional) , ... , facets (n-1 dimensional) and finally the full object. Again, we restrict ourselves to polytopes since we actually have to print the object. That is, we could not print an infinitely-large object. Not easily, at least. Next, the choice of the object- The associahedron (K5) is a polytope in which each vertex corresponds to a way of correctly inserting opening and closing parentheses in a word of 5 letters and the edges correspond to single application of the associativity rule. Finally, taking the dual of a polytope. That is, for each facet (n-1 dimensional face) assign a vertex to it's center (1 dimensional face). Then, two vertices are joined by other faces, if and only the facets share an edge. This will create a new, n dimensional, polytope. Doing so to the associahedron will generate the triaugmented triangular prism. Which is a triangular prism, where each face has a square pyramid poking out of it. More information about the Associahedron can be found here-
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Associahedron

title: Shifting paddles for Logitech Driving Force GT steering wheel

description.text:
In addition to a sequential shifter, Logitech Driving Force GT steering wheel has little nubs behind the wheel for changing gears. Those are not very nice to use.
This design is for an add-on shifting paddles that are attached around the wheel and operate by pressing those same nubs. Easy to print as all parts have a flat side. No supports needed. In addition 6 random bolts and nuts are needed for construction. 4 to attach front and back sides together and 2 to act as hinge pins on the paddles. I also have a piece of tape on both sides to keep paddles attached to the shifting nubs on the wheel. Shifting works well even when not pressing the paddles from the middle, but on one end of the paddle only. Two M4 bolts and nuts should be used as hinge pins to connect paddles to the frame. If these bolts are very loose or tight it will affect how the paddles feel like.
Attaching the to sides of the frame is easier, and size of the bolts (4) doesn't matter that much. If I recall correctly, the model was made for 5mm bolts. I even used big wood screws that I just cut to size and it has worked well for over a year already without any bolts on the back side. The v2 front plate is not such a good fit, so I improved the design not to leave a visible gap on top of the steering wheel. On the photo of my wheel, I have all v2 parts attached. Since, I have replaced it with v3.

title: Robo 3D Gopro Print Monitor Swing/Tilt Bed Mount

description.text: Use a Gopro Hero 3 to wirelessly monitor prints and or take video and timelapse. This is an easy pressure-fit plate Gopro mount for Robo 3D.  It will probably work with other 4mm glass beds. It is orientable  and hand tightens with the included special swing knobs.You will need 3 1/4" Bolts, 1/2" to 3/4" long and 3 1/4" nuts, and a standard GoPro knob/nut.

Notes: Use standard 1/4-20 nuts and hex bolts. M6 may also work. Position the GoPro frame in the yoke and push through a short hex bolt (1/2" to 3/4" long) on each side. Depending on which way you orient each of the swing knobs, they can be either trapped or removable without unthreading the nut. Push the third hex bolt though the bottom of the yoke and seat it. This bolt goes through the bed plate clamp and is snugged in place underneath with the third swing knob.
This design allows access to the usb, sd card slot, start/stop and wifi buttons, when the camera is inserted upside down (as shown). The mini hdmi, however, is inaccessible, so use a different design if you want an hdmi feed.

title: Slim 4,5mm air rifle silencer with M10x1 thread for Baikal MP-61 etc.

description.text:
Modified silencer for 4,5mm bullets with M10x1 thread, perfectly fits on Baikal MP-61 etc. Length can be adjusted by the number of segments you're printing. Use max 0,4mm Nozzle with 0,1mm layer height, otherwise thread is not high resolving enough. If possible check the avoid crossing holes function in your slicer. I recommend ABS, Nylon/Polayamid or PETG for printing.
With a slightly flexible filament (not PLA) it could be also screwed on other M10 threads. The more segments you print, the more effective it gets.
You might need glue for assembling!

title: 6 Sided Die
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: A 6 sided die created using 123D Design; the STL file that you can download is a 30x30x30mm die. The design features rounded corners and edges with indented half-spheres to indicate each number. You can easily scale up or down this die depending on how large you want it, here is a list of regulation dice sizes: http://www.dicegamedepot.com/dice-sizes/ I created the design but I used an online 3D Printing service (3D Hubs) to have the model printed because I don't currently have my own printer, therefore I'm not including in-depth printing information.:) 3D Hubs Link: https://www.3dhubs.com/
This is the die post-printing; no finishing processes were carried out :)

I designed this die using the 123D Design Program: The die started as a simple cube, I proceeded to round all of the edges and corners using the fillet tool and then began to create the dots on each face. Each dot started out as a small sphere and placed on each face of the cube using the pattern tool(s). Once each dot was in place I used the subtract tool to remove the spheres and remove the material where the spheres overlayed on the cube itself creating the indentation. 123D Design: http://www.123dapp.com/design

description.text: A simple I3 lamp to illuminate the hob gear and build plate. Lamp uses (3) 10mm Super Bright LED's, (1) 470 OHM current limiting resistor and a slide on/off switch. Originally spec'd a 68 ohm but lights started fading after a few weeks. The wiring is based on a 12volt supply. Positive lead goes to middle post on the switch, out of switch to 470 ohm resistor, out of resistor to positive lead of led (1). From there led's connect negative to positive with the final led negative connecting to the ground from the power supply. Sorry, I forgot to convert the stl to metric. Good to go now.

remixed_from.author: BrunoBellamy
remixed_from.title: NEMA17 & Bowden geared extruder for the SmartrapCore, V 0.95b

title: NEMA17 & Bowden geared extruder for the SmartrapCore, V 0.99

description.text:
Yet another geared extruder… ;) This is actually the new version I made of my previous extruder (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:678833), after many little changes and improvements. It's specially designed for my SmartrapCore printer, but it can certainly be adapted for other machines, and although I still use a wooden box SmartrapCore, it's intended to be fully compatible with the aluminium profiles model. I made its body in 3 parts that you have to stack together, so it can be printed without using material support. It's really easy to assemble, though, and it allows for a convenient way to attach it to the printer's wall (or aluminium profiles). Improvements since old version :
  • gears improved (global shape, teeth shape too) ;
  • everything is more thightly aligned and put together, to improve precision and efficiency (and less noise!) ;
  • bearrings cavities more appropriately designed ;
  • installation screw holes made compatible with both wooden box and aluminium profiles ;
  • filament output AND input holes fit for screwed pneufit ;
  • more little bunny heads in funny places. :)
    • You will need :
  • a NEMA17 step motor ;
  • a M8 hobbed bolt with the hobbed part at 25mm under the head ;
  • 2 M8 washers and 2 M8 nuts ;
  • 3 608ZZ bearings ;
  • 4 M3x25 bolts ;
  • 4 M3x10 bolts ;
  • 2 M3x50 bolts with hex head ;
  • 7 M3 nuts ;
  • 1 M3 headless screw ;
  • 2 M3 washers and springs ;
  • 2 short M3 screws for wood, or M4x10 bolts if you install this on the aluminium profiles model.
    • Look at the "assembled" STL file, it's here to show you how it should look like when fully assembled (hence the name ;))… Assemble the 3 parts of the extruder body with 2 M3x25 bolts and their nuts, then the latch with the 2 other M3 bolts and nuts, and one of the bearings.
    Install the hobbed bolt with the big gear through the assembled body with a bearing and a washer at each side, and tighten it with the 2 M8 nuts.
    Put the little gear on the motor with an M3 nut and the headless screw (don't tighten it too much, it's fragile). Install the motor on the body with the 4 M3x10 bolts. You can then tighten the little gear at the right height (there's an opening in the body front to make it easy for you).
    Insert an M3 nut in each of the holes that are on the path of the long bolts meant to tighten the latch. Put the knobs on the 50mm hex-headed M3 bolts, then the washers and springs, and insert these to tighten the latch. Don't tighten it yet, you'll do that in the end when the filament is on its way.
    Then you can install your assembled extruder in the SmartrapCore where it suits you, with the 2 screws for the wood box model or M4 bolts for the aluminium one, and plug the motor wires in. I recommend you use it with the cables holder and filament guide I also designed (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:755862) for the SmartrapCore, they really well complete each other. :) Suggestion : print the knobs with a different color from the extruder itself, it'll be more fun. ;) VERY IMPORTANT! You must set the following variables in the Configuration.h of your Marlin firmware and recompile/upload it, otherwise your new extruder won't work, and will only make scary noises without extruding anything :
    define INVERT_E0_DIR false
    define DEFAULT_AXIS_STEPS_PER_UNIT {80, 80, 80, 790}
    define DEFAULT_MAX_FEEDRATE {500, 500, 70, 70} Enjoy! :) Update (V. 0.98, oct. 2nd 2016) : re-made a body center part with more accurately threaded holes so that pneufits can be precisely and reliably screwed in place. :) Update (V. 0.99, apr 21st 2017) : made very small adjustments to the front body part, to make sure it can be installed properly on newer SmartAlu printer (it still can be installed on other SmartrapCore as well), and tightened a little bit the nut cavities on one of the latch parts.

title: Mary Poppins Parrot Umbrella Topper w/ Bluetooth speaker
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: A Mary Poppins Parrot umbrella topper, created for a cosplay prop and designed to hold a small Bluetooth speaker.

Printer:

Reach3D

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

20%

After printing, the two halves were joined over the umbrella handle using 3M double sided foam tape. Electronics were secured inside using the same. A small port was cut in the back to allow a stick to be inserted to turn off/on the Bluetooth speaker. The seam was then filled with epoxy putty, and left to harden. Once set up, the power switch stick, was stuck into place with silicone caulk and painted over. leaving a small "bump" that can be pressed to power the speaker.

The base shape came from a 3d scan by William Van Valkenberg I found here: http://www.123dapp.com/catch/Mary-Poppins-Parrot-Umbrella/4039284 I imported this into blender and scaled it to the correct size. Next I used the re-mesh tool to generate a more uniform mesh. Then chopped it in half, and subtracted some space inside for electronics. The left side is a mirrored version of the right side mesh. The "fill" parts were created to give the Bluetooth speaker cube a place to stick firmly.

title: Wanhao Duplicator I3 Z brace with adjustable feet (Hardware store special)

description.text:
Took several ideas from different parts and designed a Z axis brace and adjustable feet that includes easier to find (and cheaper) hardware. The threaded foot pads include a dovetail O-ring retainer for a 7/8" OD, 11/16 " ID O-ring (3/32" thick, AS568 -115) to dampen vibration. The foot supports have hex cut-outs to install the 3/8"-16 nuts. Fasteners used are 3/8"-16 UNC - easily sourced from hardware stores in North America. Cap head screws to attach the parts to the frame are M3-.5 x 16mm ---IMPORTANT INSTALL INFORMATION!!---
To install the mounts or feet remember to clamp the metal frame before removing any of the screws. Failure to do this could result in a twisted frame and linear rods. BOM-
Printed parts
-Z brace Bottom Left
-Z brace Bottom Right
-Z brace Top Left
-Z brace Top Right
-(2) Support foot small
-(2) Support foot large
-(6) Support foot pad, 6 is optional, 4 are required minimum. Hardware
-(20) 3/8"-16UNC grade 5 nuts
-(2) 3/8-16UNC threaded rods x 16" long
-(28) M3-.05 x 16mm cap head screws
-(6) 7/8" OD, 11/16" ID (-115) O-rings

Wanhao Di3

comments.text:
Hello. First time posting here. I finished my enclosure over the weekend from the Lack Table design (been working on for over a month) with printer in middle section of 2 stacked tables. I printed out all of your parts weeks ago for the z stabilizer and adjustable feet. I really liked the design and bought all the o-rings for feet, etc to go with the hardware. Assembled everything on the printer yesterday and all the holes lined up perfectly. The only thing I noticed was that when trying to connect the threaded rod from the upper left bracket to the lower left, even though both were very loose, I couldn't get the rod to thread in both nuts. On the right side everything threaded in fine with only the upper and lower parts being a little loose. On the left side I had to remove the lower bracket completely, thread in the rod to the both upper and lower nuts, then reattach the part back into the frame. I had to pull the rod inward w/ considerable force to get the little screws to thread in the frame from the lower plastic piece. Not sure what to adjust here as I think using this much force with twist the whole assembly which is not good.
On another note worth mentioning for anyone using this design on the lack table enclosure, after attaching the little LED lights to the ceiling of the middle section which takes only a little bit away from height clearance, I cannot get the printer to clear everything and slide in if the adjustable feet are screwed up :(. I had to remove them until I figure something out. I like this design to prevent the printer from sliding around. Is there a way the designer can make these feet a little lower so there is no nut section to it at the base (as I threaded these in by hand anyways). This may give the needed height for printer to slide in.

It does, yes. It sacrifices roughly 10mm at the top most corners . If you've ever gone up that high you'll notice you won't get 180mm without interference with the extruder wiring. So usable Z distance is closer to 170mm.

Last year i bought a 3Droid i3 Prusa with an acrylic frame and aluminium base. After 6 months of intensiv using some parts began to deform or need to be modified. I tryied to copy then as good as possible with 123Design. The Auto Bed Level arm for the servo was to short, after using a new Hotend. Later the filament lever on the extrution motor was broken apart. And last month one main part began to deform. The motor mount and hot end holder (orange ABS). I disassembled everything and with a caliper and 3 hours later, I had a nice copy. But I wasn´t happy with that. (black ABS)
So I began to build it out of metal. The first try looks very bad, but it worked out very well. Then I found some thick aluminium. So I copy my ABS model to the metal. The dimensions are the same. Only the "Hotendclamp" is 3D printed. The motor had a good cooling effect thru the metal. Because of the smooth surface of the Hotend not wobble.

description.text: You can use this apparatus for solvent welding multiple lengths of plastic T-Slot < http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:10261 > together. The jig will allow you to compensate for warped beams and produce straight and usable T-Slot of arbitrary length.

The process below is for T-Slot printed in ABS. PLA will need an active element other than ABS Glue to bond the beams. Gather the materials listed. If you don't have any ABS Glue < http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:14490 > make some out of the filament you are using to print the beams. Print enough of the Welding Jig STL so that the angle bar won't deflect when pressing down on it. I space them about 8 inches apart with two more placed directly beneath where I'm about to fuse. You want the beams to fit in the channel and lay as flat as possible; clip off any blobs and sand off the flange at the bottom if one is present, if you print lots of these you'll find the sweet spot in flow-rate/starting-Z-height and be able to completely eliminate that bulge at the bottom. Depending on your settings you may also have a slight bulge at the very top located at the seam, sand or razor only the bulge off. Brush ABS Glue on the end of the beams, place them in the jig and gently press together and down, constraining the beams against the sides of the jig. Let the beams set, give them a few minutes too be certain they are fully bonded. Don't worry if they are not exactly co-linear, multiple beams fused along the length of the channel will compensate for any individual misalignment.

title: Gear generator for Solidworks (Straight / Helix / Herringbone)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
• True involute curve profiled teeth - no spline approximation
  • Customisable teeth, depth, module & pressure angle
  • Configurable helix
  • Herringbone capable
    • See instructions for detailed info...

V1
  • Initial Upload
    • V1.1
  • Added offset option to allow for printing tolerances
  • Changed top and bottom plane definition for right and left twist to be more consistent through new configurations
  • Consolidated root extrude feature into tooth profile cut
  • Added controls for offset amount and suppression state in design table to allow for 0 offset
  • Renamed a few features
    • V1.2
  • Added approximate profile shifting for gears below 20x Teeth
  • Added mating profile for tangency mating of gears
  • Added gear profile for gear ratio mate
  • Adjusted how the herringbone is generated as it broke on some configurations
<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/bNHRu0RPF0M" ></iframe>

This is a pinion gear generation part for solidworks with options for helical and herringbone tooth profiles.
Using design tables within solidworks, you'll be able to customise as many pinion gear configurations as desired. There are some limitations with what can be generated, which are detailed with a brief description of each parameter below

• Teeth - Integer value
    Number of teeth on the gear. This is minimum limited to about 10-12 teeth duer to the drastic change in tooth profile required if you want teeth quantities less than this.

  • Module - Non-integer positive value
    The circumference reference pitch of each tooth. Usually a multiple of 0.25mm. Minimum printing value is about 1.5-2mm for a 0.4mm nozzle. Any less and your gear will have critical geometry smaller than you can reliably print.

  • Pressure angle - Non-integer positive value
    The angle to the tangent where two mated gears mesh fully that the tooth engagement will follow. This is a standard at 20deg and should rarely be altered.

  • Gear width - Non-integer positive value
    The gear width is the measurement between both circular faces of each side of the gear. In a herringbone configuration, this value is doubled.

  • Helix angle - Non-integer positive value
    The helix angle is the angle of rotation with respect to the gears' axis. 0 degrees is a straight cut pinion gear, and 90degrees is an infinite number of twists and will probably crash your instance of solidworks!

  • Right hand / Left hand helix - Boolean
    The right hand and left hand helix options dictate whether your helix angle will rotate clockwise (right hand) or counter clockwise (left hand) along the width of the gear.
    These options are chosen by unsuppressing either the "twist right" or "twist left" feature states in the design table. Both shouldn't be unsuppressed at the same time

  • Herringbone tooth profile - Boolean
    The herringbone tooth profile option will literally mirror the helix pinion gear about the far-side circular face of the gear. The helix angle will then be reversed, and a herringbone tooth profile will be created.
    This profile is used by many extruders (wades being the most popular) as a herringbone profile will remove almost all axial load (not usually desirable) on the gear.

  • Offset - Non-integer positive value
    The offset shown in the screenshot attached to this thing will reduce the tooth edges along the profile of the tooth, including the root of the tooth (the tip is not reduced with the offset parameter) by a dimension specified by this design table entry. I have not printed using this feature yet, but I can imagine you'd need a small offset of about 0.05 to 0.1mm to account for printing inaccuracies. This saves the need to sand each tooth to size after printing.
    • Options shown in yellow in the design table screenshot are the only values to be changed by the user. The other values should be copied to all configurations as they are calculated within the design table.

• 3D printer co-ordinates
    Make sure, when exporting the STL from solidworks, you open the options panel in the "Save As..." dialog, and use the "3D Printer coords" coordinate system as your coordinate reference. Otherwise, machining coordinates will be applied, and your gear will have to be rotated on your slicer's bed. Saves annoyance. Trust me.

  • Meshing Reference
    Within the model, the pinion gear has a specific diameter circle about the axis that should be used when mating gears together tangentially. I keep the "Meshing reference" sketch visible when using these gears in a solidworks assembly as it makes it easy to mesh gears with the mate tool. Rotating each gear prior to making a "gear mate" is required by hand unfortunately. I can't think of an elegant way to define this in a sketch and allow gears to be rotated in an assembly.

• All measurements are in mm. Sorry yanks! (although easily changeable)

  • I am still yet to print one of these gears, so please, if you make one, post a "made" submission!

  • I've added a pair of small herringbone gears STL's for anyone to print as a tester. Settings for these gears are provided in the solidworks part as "Demo R" and "Demo L". Both should mesh along the entire tooth profile of both gears.

  • Note the licensing of the tool. Please attribute where this tool has been used. Thanks

Here is a slotted friction fit faceplate design for 20mm Plastic T-Slot < http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:10261 >. Holes are provided to accommodate M3 bolts either for permanent mounting or to hold in place while framing. As a fully printable hardware system, the holes provide a place to dribble acetone permanently adhering beam to plate. When using bolts take care not to over tighten.
Print face up without support. The main failure mode for this piece will be de-lamination of the face to the slot and groove. Printing too fast, too cool, or overcooling can cause this.

comments.text: I think I had some really minor sanding to do on the pins, my printer's tolerances on such things tends to be around 0.2 mm larger than the size I design.  The top_led_tab_3mm holds two blue 3 mm led's and slides into a slot in the core_file piece.  The front and rear_tab's go in the 4 slots on the grip.  Those I've had issues with fitting, needing to be printed at a smaller size.  I redesigned the lightcore so that I could cut out a piece of clear acrylic with a hole saw to diffuse the lighting.  I'm working on another pair of guns this evening so I'll double check what size it is and maybe take some pictures.  The clear acrylic goes in, the ring should fit and the cap just gets glued on the acrylic so that it looks to be floating.

comments.text: Any chance we can get this one in different length/width? say 2x2, 1x2,1x3, etc etc? I know a lot of people prefer their wood stl files to have wood texture but frankly it looks out of place for say a tavern with a lot of foot traffic over the wood. I prefer this style of wood floor and want to use it in my tavern build but having started printing yet for this reason of not having the different tile variations. Also on a final note...Im surprised and perhaps an idea, I havent seen anyone doing simple 0.5inch h/w rectangular pieces of wood for simple wall indicators. I simply cannot stand these full 3d dungeons and all 18 of my player base cant see how the blocking of being able to see the room justifies the immersion. For our table we use hurst art stone mold walls (1 high) to indicate there is a wall between the floor tiles but not blocking the play board. (with the exception of walls that need to be visible if there is a door/window etc)To my knowledge if you did a 1 square, 2 square etc wood rectangle wall indicator it would be the first of its kind and we would all LOVE IT.
comments.author: RPGStoryteller

comments.text: Interesting idea. Never thought about making this one different sizes. I'll look into it. Working on some other stuff right now but if I get time it shouldn't take too long. As for the partial walls, I could just make simple rectangles if that's what people would want to set on top of the tiles to indicate walls.
comments.author: RPGStoryteller

comments.text: Thank you for the reply. Would be awesome. On the rectangle pieces we set them in between the tiles so we can use the complete floor space of the tiles. Attempted to do it myself but new to 3d design and 3d printing for that matter and cant get the board lines like you have above in them to give them a little flavor without trying to complicate the print. Also tempted to fuse the tiles pieces above to make my own 2x2 etc variations before bothering you with this...but that attempted failed as well lol. On a side note although i dont like the wood grain design on tiles...it would however give a cool look and definition to separate them from the floor tiles if used on the wall indicators. So that would be cool.
comments.author: donald_stouffer

comments.text:
It's nice to see at least someone's got wood...
How about some different types of boards and arrangements? Irregular widths, lengths; trapdoor; patterns; etc. Also how about some thin, flat, long planks, say base scale of about 1/3" wide, to use for carts, gangplanks, falling lumber, battering ram, etc.? And then some ladders, either good quality or haphazard arrangements. Then I'll want a wooden horse big enough that I could make it a gift to some Trojans.
comments.author: MarauderX

comments.text: wow, that's a lot of suggestions! Very interesting stuff. Would love to make some carts and traps.

title: Battery case for the Sword of Omens (Thundercats, 1980s)

description.text:
Found this dinged up and abandoned at a schoolyard where I grew up, missing the battery cap; anyone have the dimensions for that?  I figure the metal bit and/or spring won't be too hard to come by - a standard AA coil hot-glued to the center should do the trick, making constant contact.
I'm guessing on all the pommel dimensions, since obviously I don't have one to measure - if anyone Does have one, I'd be happy to update this.  Barring that, this is what you get, hope it works out for you.

Notes: This model is dependent on 3 things going right.

  • The main hole for the magnet should get a very nice grip to the bed surface. However with a Dremel you could scratch away any warping in post.

  • The bridging for the magnet hole. The hole is about 5mm tall. And I have risen the body to 6.6mm tall giving a nice cushion of 8 layers at .2 to smooth out.

  • Finally is the color change at the end of layer 6.6
    • First off I use Octoprint to run my printer. And have been told this can work with Repetier Host, Pronterface, or Cura I watch the Gcode viewer until it gets to the very last move on the layer before I change. Overshooting and getting a bit on the next layer is not the end of the world. I hit the Pause button, and immediately go to controls and drive the head off of the part. I then retract the current color by 50-75mm in increments of 25 (Be sure to remember exactly how much you retract) Pull that color out and replace with your new color. Pushing it as far into the extruder as you can by hand (Try as hard as you can to not more the head) Extrude in the exact same amount as your retracted. Be near by to clean the head as it builds up on the bed. Pull the extra material away. And hit resume. It should remember the X, Y, and extruder motor positions and return to that point and begins printing again! And finally. using the craft magnets mentioned in the main post. I Simply line up the hole with the magnet and press firmly down to snap it into place. If the hole seems a bit too small. I recommend a screwdriver or Dremel to scrape off a bit of extra plastic. If the hole becomes too wide. I use a strong crafting glue, or some super glue in the hole and press and hold the magnet until they are stuck together.

You can go now of holidays whithout to be worried about water your plants, choose a 300ml or a liter bottle ( coke cap)  depending the time (one week/ month) you need and with water-dropper you will maintain  the moisture of the sand for more . You can adjust the  size of the hole.
